title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [10–15 april 1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [10–15 April 1873]
text: 12 April 1873My dear waltWalt i have just receevedreceived your letter this stormy morning with the dollar in sometimes i want a little change but dontdon't send it only once in a while) i have thought walterWalter dear that you must have had more expenceexpense since you have been sick than you had before but there dontdon't seem to be any consideration eddsEdd's board is expected just the samei have got the 2 other letters) you needentneedn't direct them to georgeGeorge and the foundry without you would rather as the letter man always brings them georgeGeorge is not there half of the time as he has work for mrMr. Lane at florenceFlorence and glowcesterGloucester he gets his 8 dollars a day from the new york work) there is a large contract from bostonBoston given out to the glosterGloucester foundry georgeGeorge thinks he will get the inspecting of it it is about 4 miles from here so you see waltWalt the more we have the more we want) i suppose if i needed georgeGeorge would help me but he has never given me 50 cents since i have been heereherei dontdon't think but what i am welcome here from georgeGeorge Lou sometimes says when she and georgeGeorge was alone they got this and that but now theresthere's so manya woman can doodo very much to have a man think different from what things really isgeorgeGeorge is more changed in some respects than i could ever beleivebelieve he gives the strecteststrictest account of every thing and if he goes out you wontwon't be gone more than 10 minutes it seemesseems so strange for him as he always went when he preasedpleased and come when he liked) aunt Lib as they call her is here and i gessguess will be here for some timtime Lou says georgeGeorge likes to have her here i like her well enoughfenough i think likely she will make her home here) Lou hasenthasn't been down stairs since last tuesdayTuesday till this morning georgeGeorge carried her down he carries her up and down then she goes out in the kichenkitchengod forgive me if i judge wrongfully but i dontdon't think there is much the matterdear waltWalt you mustentmustn't think i complain but i think if i had sombodysomebody to talk a little with i should feel releevedrelieved so i have to bother you with my gossip good bie walterWalter dear you must write often i was going to write to you to send an envelope for Jeff georgesGeorge's house is going on there is a cellar under the whole houshouse and a bay window is Lou sLou's bed room) and built for 37 hundrd) instead of 38 Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [10–15 April 1873]
